title: TIPP (Rapid Body Reset)
summary: Quickly lower extreme emotion by shocking the body back toward a calm baseline through temperature, exercise, breathing, and muscle relaxation.

details.content: Intense emotions ride on high physiological arousal. Rapidly shifting the body’s chemistry (heart rate, vagal tone) can cut the peak within minutes.
Plunge your face into a bowl of cold water or hold an ice pack for 30 seconds; your heart rate drops and panic subsides enough to think clearly.

content: T – Cool face or neck with icy water (mimics a diving reflex).
I – Do 20–60 seconds of burpees or jumping jacks.
P – Slow, paced breathing: 4‑count in, 6‑count out.
P – Pair exhale with Progressive Muscle Relaxation (clench‑release).

title: Self‑Soothe with the Five Senses
summary: Use sight, sound, smell, taste, and touch to create a calm micro‑environment when emotions run hot.

details.content: Pleasant sensory input sends ‘safety’ cues to the brain’s threat system, dampening cortisol and interrupting rumination.
Light a lavender candle, wrap in a soft blanket, and listen to rainfall audio while anger cools.

content: Make a portable ‘soothe kit’ (earbuds, scent vial, tea bag, photo).
Immerse fully—notice texture, temperature, flavor for 30‑60 s.
Rotate senses to avoid adaptation (e.g., sight + sound today, smell + touch tomorrow).

title: ACCEPTS Distraction Skills
summary: Short‑term distractions that buy time until the emotional wave passes—Activities, Contributing, Comparisons, opposite Emotions, Pushing away, Thoughts, Sensations.

details.content: When urges are overwhelming, healthy distraction prevents impulsive actions that could make things worse (self‑harm, yelling, substance use).
Do a 10‑minute puzzle (Activity), text an encouraging meme to a friend (Contributing), recall a time you survived worse (Comparison), etc.

content: Pre‑list 3 options for each ACCEPTS letter in your phone.
Set a timer (10‑20 min) to ensure distraction is deliberate, not avoidance.
Combine letters for stronger effect (e.g., brisk walk + uplifting playlist = Activity + opposite Emotion).

title: IMPROVE the Moment
summary: Change your internal experience of a painful situation through imagery, meaning, prayer, relaxation, one‑thing‑in‑the‑moment, vacation, or encouragement.

details.content: Even when you can’t fix the external problem, adjusting mindset and physiology reduces suffering and preserves problem‑solving capacity.
Waiting for test results, you visualize a safe beach (Imagery), repeat a calming mantra (Encouragement), and focus on feeling the chair beneath you (One thing).

content: Pair two elements—for instance, deep breathing (Relaxation) while silently repeating ‘this too shall pass’ (Encouragement).
Keep ‘vacation’ micro—step outside for 5 minutes under a tree.
Personalize meaning: ask, ‘What lesson might this challenge offer me?’

title: Pros & Cons Before Acting
summary: Weigh the short‑ and long‑term consequences of acting on an urge versus using a skill or doing nothing.

details.content: Putting the urge into a cost‑benefit frame recruits the logical brain, reducing impulsivity and clarifying motivation to use skills.
Write four boxes: Pros of yelling, Cons of yelling, Pros of walking away, Cons of walking away—seeing the list curbs the urge to lash out.

content: Do it on paper first; once learned, run it mentally in 60 seconds.
Underline long‑term costs—they often outweigh short‑term relief.
Review the sheet after the crisis to reinforce wise choices.

title: STOP Skill for Immediate Grounding
summary: S‑Stop, T‑Take a step back, O‑Observe, P‑Proceed mindfully—four micro‑steps to prevent knee‑jerk reactions.

details.content: The first seconds of a crisis often decide outcome. STOP inserts a pause that keeps you from escalating damage.
Email arrives that feels insulting: you freeze hands over keyboard (Stop), push chair back (Take a step), notice racing heart (Observe), then draft a calm reply (Proceed mindfully).

content: Pair with a physical cue—touch thumb to forefinger when you ‘Stop.’
Use a silent exhale on the ‘T’ step to trigger parasympathetic response.
Rehearse aloud in calm moments so it’s automatic under stress.

title: Radical Acceptance & Turning the Mind
summary: End needless suffering by fully accepting reality as it is, then repeatedly redirecting the mind back to acceptance whenever it drifts to resistance.

details.content: Pain is inevitable; resisting ‘what is’ adds secondary suffering. Acceptance frees energy for wise action (or peaceful endurance when change isn’t possible).
After a breakup you cannot change, you notice anger rising, label it ‘non‑acceptance,’ breathe, and mentally say, ‘Yes, this happened.’ Repeat each time resentment returns.

content: Use half‑smile and willing‑hands posture to cue acceptance in the body.
Distinguish acceptance (acknowledging facts) from approval (liking them).
Expect to ‘turn the mind’ dozens of times—the pivot itself is the skill.
